Question_1.Context: The study focuses on the immobilization of lipase TLLs within a hydrogel matrix. The researchers utilized a two-step crosslinking method involving oxidized carboxymethyl cellulose (OCMC) and carboxymethyl chitosan (CMCHS).
Question_1.Question: What was the primary method used to immobilize lipase TLLs within the hydrogel matrix?
Question_1.Source: TLLs were initially crosslinked through the Schiff base reaction by oxidized carboxymethyl cellulose (OCMC).

Question_2.Context: The study evaluated the impact of different solvents on the catalytic performance of the hydrogel-encapsulated lipase TLLs.
Question_2.Question: Which solvent exhibited the highest conversion rate of 6'-O-lauroyl arbutin in the enzymatic reaction?
Question_2.Source: After a reaction at 50 °C for 12 h, the conversion rate of 6'-O-lauroyl arbutin in different reaction media was found to be in descending order, i.e., THF > tert-amyl alcohol > acetone > cyclohexane > acetonitrile > methanol.

Question_3.Context: The study investigated the enzymatic properties of the hydrogel-encapsulated lipase TLLs, focusing on factors such as pH and temperature.
Question_3.Question: What was the optimal pH for both free TLLs and CMCHS/OCMC@TLLs?
Question_3.Source: The optimum pH of free TLLs and CMCHS/OCMC@TLLs was found to be approximately 8.0.

Question_4.Context: The study analyzed the enzymatic kinetic parameters of free TLLs, OCMC@TLLs complex, and OCMC/CMCS@TLLs using the Michaelis-Menten equation.
Question_4.Question: What was the Km value of OCMC/CMCS@TLLs compared to free TLLs?
Question_4.Source: The Km of OCMC/CMCS@TLLs was calculated to be 9.938 mmol/L, about sevenfold higher than that of free TLLs.

Question_5.Context: The study assessed the inhibitory activity of tyrosinase by comparing α-arbutin and 6'-O-lauroyl arbutin.
Question_5.Question: Which compound exhibited a lower IC50 value for inhibiting tyrosinase?
Question_5.C: Both had the same IC50 value
Question_5.Source: The IC50 value of 6’-O-lauroyl arbutin was 0.035 mmol/L, slightly lower than that of α-arbutin (0.041 mmol/L).

Question_6.Context: The study investigated the DPPH radical scavenging ability of α-arbutin and 6'-O-lauroyl arbutin.
Question_6.Question: Which compound showed a greater DPPH radical scavenging ability?
Question_6.Source: The DPPH radical scavenging ability of 6’-O-lauroyl arbutin was found to be greater than that of its parent compound.

Question_7.Context: The study evaluated the operating stability of OCMC/CMCHS@TLLs in comparison to a commercially immobilized lipase preparation.
Question_7.Question: Which catalyst exhibited a higher residual activity after seven repetitions of the reaction?
Question_7.C: Both had the same residual activity
Question_7.Source: After seven repetitions, the performance of OCMC/CMCHS@TLLs dropped to 53.52%, suggesting its high operating stability.

Question_8.Context: The study analyzed the Log P values of arbutin and 6'-O-lauroyl arbutin to determine their hydrophilicity and lipophilicity.
Question_8.Question: What was the Log P value of 6'-O-lauroyl arbutin compared to arbutin?
Question_8.A: Arbutin had a higher Log P value
Question_8.B: 6'-O-lauroyl arbutin had a higher Log P value
Question_8.C: Both had the same Log P value
Question_8.Source: The Log P value of α-arbutin was -1.51, indicating its potent hydrophilicity; however, the Log P value of 6’-O-lauroyl arbutin was as high as 3.18, demonstrating that the lipophilicity of arbutin was greatly enhanced.

Question_9.Context: The study assessed the impact of acylation modification on the inhibitory activity of tyrosinase.
Question_9.Question: Which compound showed a lower IC50 value for inhibiting tyrosinase?
Question_9.C: Both had the same IC50 value
Question_9.Source: The IC50 value of 6’-O-lauroyl arbutin was about 0.12 mmol/L, obviously lower than that of α-arbutin.

Question_10.Context: The study evaluated the DPPH radical scavenging ability of α-arbutin and 6'-O-lauroyl arbutin.
Question_10.Question: Which compound exhibited a greater DPPH radical scavenging ability?
Question_10.Source: The DPPH radical scavenging ability of 6’-O-lauroyl arbutin was greatly higher than its parent compound due to the electron-donating effect of lauroyl groups.
